customer_addr:
440 Red Top Rd
Valley View, TX 76272

citations.narrative:
The facility is allowing the public to hold an adult sloth. The sloth could easily bite someone on the neck with the way it is
held. Sloths have the potential to inflict serious bites that can become easily infected and/or serious scratches with their
long claws if they become agitated or scared. There is also the potential for the sloth to become injured if a child or adult
accidentally drops the animal.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023

The facility is allowing the public to feed the giraffe without an attendant present. The facility offers overnight
accommodation in suites attached to the giraffe barn. Two of these suites have small windows the guests can open and
feed the giraffe at any time without an attendant present. The facility does provide food appropriate for the giraffe but
without an attendant, the facility cannot confirm the giraffe is not being offered food that could be harmful to his health. A
responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023

The facility is allowing primates that are not under direct control of an experienced handler to sit on the head and
shoulders of visitors. Nonhuman primates used in uncaged public exhibits must be under the direct control and
supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times when the public is present. Primates should not be allowed on
the heads and shoulders of visitors. Primates can easily injure a person before an attendant can consciously respond to
control them. Trained nonhuman primates may be permitted physical contact with the public, as allowed under § 2.131,
but only if they are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times during the
contact.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility is allowing the public to hold an adult sloth. The sloth could easily bite someone on the neck with the way it is 
held. Sloths have the potential to inflict serious bites that can become easily infected and/or serious scratches with their 
long claws if they become agitated or scared. There is also the potential for the sloth to become injured if a child or adult 
accidentally drops the animal. 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public.  
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility is allowing the public to feed the giraffe without an attendant present. The facility offers overnight 
accommodation in suites attached to the giraffe barn. Two of these suites have small windows the guests can open and 
feed the giraffe at any time without an attendant present. The facility does provide food appropriate for the giraffe but 
without an attendant, the facility cannot confirm the giraffe is not being offered food that could be harmful to his health. A 
responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact.  
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023 
3.77(g) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The facility is allowing primates that are not under direct control of an experienced handler to sit on the head and 
shoulders of visitors. Nonhuman primates used in uncaged public exhibits must be under the direct control and 
supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times when the public is present. Primates should not be allowed on 
the heads and shoulders of visitors. Primates can easily injure a person before an attendant can consciously respond to 
control them. Trained nonhuman primates may be permitted physical contact with the public, as allowed under § 2.131, 
but only if they are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times during the 
contact.  
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
